I forgot who proposed it, but I liked the idea that the universe came to be because nothingness violates the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. All the unknowable pairs would be knowable in a universe with no volume, no time, and (seemingly?) unlimited energy. Whether there be any truth to that or not I don't know, but I find the idea cute.

Science can't answer the question so it continually backs-up the chain of life as it discovers things in the Now. However it cannot answer the ultimate question of Being. I think scientists are frustrated at that paradox. Substituting the inability to answer the paradox causes such immense frustration that that vacuum is filled with a "positive" declaration that there is no God because science has no evidence. This however is an illusion because all being is the evidence.
.
I'm guessing you see the problem. Hope is the expectation of good things to come, in the face of lack of evidence. Without hope, all that remains is nihilism - that being cannot be understood and life is meaningless.
.

That is the same reason why "supernatural" things can't posibly exist, because if they did, by definition they wouldn't be supernatural (because natural means things that exist).

Of course it may be, that science in the future will find, that a god created the world, but it is a common measure to make as few extraordinary assumptions in science as possible and until now there has been no known instance that a god is the NECECARY cause of something. In most cases the assumption that we just don't know enough get's us a lot further-


TL/DR: Things can't be supernatural, if they existed, they would be natural, because that is, what natural means. Supernatural includes in it's definition that something doesn't exist. And in my experience God is conceived as a "supernatural" being.

In order to measure something, you need to compare it to something else. If you are in a car, it appears to you that your and the car are stationary, and it's the Earth that is the one moving. But to someone watching you in the car, it appears to them as though the Earth is stationary, and you are the one moving. And to a bird flying in the opposite direction of the car, it appears as though the Earth is moving, and the car is moving even faster. There is not one definitive answer. They are all moving and not moving depending on the object or point in space that their position is being compared to.
So how can you definitely say that the universe expanded? In order to make that assertion, you need to compare its increase in size relative to something else. So what is that something else?

1:57 "...laboratory-confirmed physics..."
- to justify the existence of matter (and how anti matter once existed), which is onyl one of theories about matter/anti-matter and not necessarily closest to the truth.
2:10 "...for reasons unknown..."
- to push forward a thinking that somehow (for reasons unknown) the symmetry between matter and anti-matter became unequal, leading to the inevitable eradication of all anti-matter, leaving us with what we define as matterial universe.
please be aware that that is a theory pushed forward by entertaining the idea that there is somehow unexplainable reasons why there could be a disruption in the symmetry of matter and anti-matter, which is a theory among many.
NOTE: unknown reasons to a cause that resulted in something, DOES NOT necessarily verify any theory describing the origin of that something.
5:34 "...by mechanism unknown..."
- to explain how life came into existence
7:04 "...to INVENT astrophysics..."
- to invent. not to discover.
Astrophysics according to space.com is a branch of space science that applies the laws of physics and chemistry to explain the birth, life and death of stars, planets, galaxies, nebulae and other objects in the universe.
mind you, applying scientific facts from the cummulative knowledge of the human race is a noble effort but until proven otherwise, it is, in every single sense of the word, A THEORY.
yet pay attention to time marker 7:30 "... one might even say we are empowered by it (the universe) to figure itself out..."
that's philosophical rather than scientific.

but time marker 7:32 is tricky, it said "...and we've only just begun..."

Ok so I figured I would give my opinion on this because why not? A lot of people are saying that when he says things like "reasons unknown" a lot that is pointing to some sort of supreme being or "God" if you will. That is not necessarily true, but it is not necessarily false either. Someone in the comments said "It's like we have 75% of a puzzle, so we make up the other 25% in a way which makes the most sense to us." I feel like that sums it up really well. Think about it this way: A really bad car crash happens and there are no survivors or witnesses. The people tasked with investigating this crash have a lot of facts to go by, and can figure out pretty much what happened. However, without actually being there to see it happen they can't know 100% for sure exactly what happened. But they can make educated guesses based on past knowledge and research. The universe is sort of the same way. Yes that is a really basic analogy but what I'm saying is that without being there to actually experience the creation of the universe, we don't actually know. Saying that because we don't have all the answers means that there has to be a God is ridiculous. Also, saying that because the big bang and evolution have been scientifically proven that must disprove a God is ridiculous. Almost every argument for or against a god can be countered by the same argument; for example if someone says "well if the universe wasn't created by a god then what created it?" that can be countered by "well if god created the universe then what created god?" and vice versa. So I say live the life you want to live. Explore the origins of the universe if you wish. Believe that God created everything in an instant if that's what you believe. Share your opinions with the world, but don't hate other people for not believing the same thing you do. Every single person has their own path to take, their own journey, and their own questions to answer. Let them travel that path without fear or judgement.

Dear Neil,

Thank you for this wonderful overview of history's history.  I myself am an astronomer, and over the years I've been listening to your wonderful contributions to the development of scientific knowledge of the layman. However, as a researcher of evolved low-mass stars, I would like take the liberty to point to a singular piece of inaccurate information that you consistently convey in your messages. It concerns the (higher than ten solar-mass) origin of intermediate-mass elements.

Using a basic prescription of the initial mass function it is easy to calculate that about 96% of all matter contained in (pre, peri and post) helium-burning stars will be on the low-mass (less than 8 solar masses) end. These stars will eventually end-up on the asymptotic giant branch (AGB), after which they will blow themselves out in a beautiful planetary nebula (PN). During the AGB phase, some simple thermonuclear fusion is periodically (see thermal pulse (TP)) turning H into He and He into C and O. However, in the He intershell the s-process thrives, producing a wide spectrum of heavier elements up to bismuth and polonium. Via large-scale convective motions all this enriched material is dredged up (third dredge-up) to the surface of the star, where it is ejected via pulsations (kappa mechanism) and forms a cool, molecule-rich and dust-rich stellar wind. This wind increases in intensity until the entire mantle of the star is ejected, and only the bare C/O core remains (PN + white dwarf).

The interstellar medium (ISM) is thus primarily enriched with low- and intermediate-mass elements via this process. 

I hope I have provoked your curiosity on the matter, and anticipate the moment when you'll give some credit to the hard work of my darling AGB stars :)

The Big Bang theory doesn't make any sense to me.  All of the matter in the universe existed in one tiny point that exploded and created everything?  Where did the point come from?  How and why did it exist?  It seems that the fact that these questions are far from being answered would be a hint that maybe this didn't happen.  From what I know, the Big Bang theory comes from the fact that the universe is constantly expanding, which we have measured, but aren't there many better, more believable reasons why the universe would be expanding?  Maybe outside of the observable universe somewhere there is actually a perfect vacuum; actual nothingness, and the universe is expanding to fill that empty space.  Of course I've never seen or understood the measurements that suggested that the Big Bang happened.  There are also probably many more reasons that would suggest that it happened, that I simply don't know.  But it seems that there should be more evidence than there is for such a widely accepted theory.  Maybe I'm just missing something, what do I know?  Does anyone have more possible proof for the Big Bang?
